sentences.sentence: This editorial originally appeared(https://tj.news/telegraph-journal/102123876) at the The Telegraph-Journal in Saint John, New Brunswick.New Brunswick politicians need to pump the brakes in the charged debate(https://nationalpost.com/news/n-b-premier-prepared-to-call-election-over-lgbtq-schools-policy) over Policy 713.

The Tories' efforts to amend(https://nationalpost.com/news/n-b-premier-prepared-to-call-election-over-lgbtq-schools-policy) the document, which governs the treatment of LGBTQ students in public schools, have been a controversy for weeks.
Now, it's time to dampen the emotion and work out a productive solution.What we certainly don't need is an election.
Yet less than three years into his majority mandate, Premier Blaine Higgs mused Thursday that it may be time to take the matter to voters.This would be irresponsible.
An issue as complex and sensitive as this one calls out for good governance and policymaking, not a show of hands.Policy 713 is the product of many years of research.
On the issue of name changes for transgender students, the original document places a high emphasis on privacy.

In essence, it says that if Joe wants to be called Jane, the school will respect these wishes; and it is up to the student to decide if and when to come out of the closet to their parents.It strikes us as a reasonable approach, and not an effort to indoctrinate anyone on Woke gender ideology.

But the premier feels quite strongly that the policy does not account for the rights of parents, whom he says should be consulted before schools agree to use a different name and pronoun for a student.No doubt there are many New Brunswickers who agree with him.

But there should be a way to address their views and concerns without indulging two bad options: unilaterally rewriting the policy (which the Tories have now done), or heading to the polls.A favourable early-election result for the premier would not vindicate his government's poor handling of this issue.
And if he loses, the Liberals would likely undo much of his excellent record, including population growth, debt reduction and tax cuts.

Going down the election road should be off the table.However, we think there's a way for the premier to advance his concerns about 713 without indulging his "my way or the highway" style.It starts by acknowledging that he and Education Minister Bill Hogan went about this all wrong.
On a touchy, difficult issue, a minister should not be rewriting carefully crafted policy just because the premier likes the idea.

Hogan should rescind the new changes, pending further work.The Tories should then appoint an independent person, familiar with the issue and credible to both sides, to advise cabinet on how to better incorporate parents' rights and concerns.
He or she could also recommend the appropriate amount of public input needed to make changes.That's an approach people would respect.There is nothing inherently wrong with revisiting this policy.

But the premier needs to do it the right way by consulting more, instead of upping the political brinkmanship.Brunswick NewsMartin Wightman: If Irving Oil leaves New Brunswick, Justin Trudeau will be to blame(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/martin-wightman-if-irving-oil-leaves-new-brunswick-justin-trudeau-will-be-to-blame)Kenneth Green: Canada's burning because of bad forest policy, not climate change(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/canadas-burning-because-of-bad-forest-policy-not-climate-change) !
@COPYRIGHT=Â© 2023 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
